Banksy 0.99.0

    • Working with BanksyObjects

    Working with BanksyObject

    banksy-object.Rmd

    This article describes the BanksyObject class in detail and how to interact with it.

    Class structure

    An object of the BanksyObject class can be constructed as follows:

    library(Banksy)
bank <- BanksyObject()

    BanksyObject has the following slots:

    slotNames(bank)
#> [1] "own.expr"             "nbr.expr"             "own.norm.scaled.expr"
#> [4] "nbr.norm.scaled.expr" "custom.expr"          "cell.locs"           
#> [7] "meta.data"            "dim.reduction"
    • own.expr stores the raw gene-cell expression matrix
    • nbr.expr stores the neighbour feature-cell expression matrix
    • own.norm.scaled.expr stores the normalized / scaled gene-cell expression matrix
    • nbr.norm.scaled.expr stores the normalized / scaled neighbour feature-cell expression matrix
    • custom.expr is an auxillary slot for storing a custom expression matrix
    • cell.locs stores the cell locations
    • meta.data stores cell metadata, such as cluster labels or colours for visualisation
    • dim.reduction stores dimension reductions

    Getter and setter methods are defined for each of these slots. To illustrate these functionalities, we use the data attached with the package.

    expr <- readRDS(system.file('/extdata/expression.rds', package = 'Banksy'))
locs <- readRDS(system.file('/extdata/locations.rds', package = 'Banksy'))

    The BanksyObject can be constructed by supplying the gene-cell expression matrix and cell locations.

    bank <- BanksyObject(own.expr = expr,
                     cell.locs = locs)

bank
#> class: BanksyObject 
#> own expression: 6725 cells 140 features
#> neighbour expression: NULL
#> own norm. scaled expression: NULL
#> neighbour norm. scaled expression: NULL
#> spatial dimensions: sdimx sdimy 
#> metadata names: cell_ID 
#> dimension reductions:

    The dataset consists of 6725 cells, 140 genes, with 2 spatial dimensions.

    Calling ComputeBanksy computes the neighbour feature-cell expression matrix, and the normalized / scaled matrices (if applicable).

    bank <- ComputeBanksy(bank)
#> Performing normalization...
#> Computing Banksy matrices...
#> Spatial mode is kNN_r, k_geom = 10
#> Banksy matrix: 75.317 sec elapsed
head(bank)
#> own expression:
#>          cell_4 cell_5 cell_6 cell_7 cell_8
#> Slc1a2        4      2     13     26      6
#> Scn4b         3      6     17      0      1
#> Itpr1         3      0     15      2      3
#> Slc25a23      3      0      5      3      1
#> Slc1a3        1      1      0     31      2
#> 
#> neighbour expression:
#>                  cell_4    cell_5    cell_6     cell_7    cell_8
#> Slc1a2.nbr   13.3675515  9.368771 12.924615 18.6090160 7.0747304
#> Scn4b.nbr    12.2899129 11.823595  3.835253  0.7785696 6.2881769
#> Itpr1.nbr     9.8955359  6.848816  6.066940  2.0368563 7.0974742
#> Slc25a23.nbr  4.4993349  3.322921  4.182612  3.1487999 4.5403533
#> Slc1a3.nbr    0.5861533  1.898213  3.879938  9.2377217 0.8455385
#> 
#> own normalized scaled expression:
#>              cell_4      cell_5      cell_6     cell_7     cell_8

#> Scn4b    0.99247300  2.34103607  0.33303211 -0.8955153 -0.4980441

#> Slc1a3   0.08799831 -0.02038541 -0.67068773  4.1537773  0.2876525
#> 
#> neighbour normalized scaled expression:
#>                  cell_4      cell_5      cell_6     cell_7      cell_8

#> Scn4b.nbr     1.2143448  1.12529087 -0.40026292 -0.9840055  0.06817814

#> Slc25a23.nbr  0.4707495 -0.43577232  0.22668938 -0.5699463  0.50235743
#> Slc1a3.nbr   -1.0116741 -0.59017759  0.04644743  1.7676245 -0.92834715
#> 
#> cell locations:
#>            sdimx     sdimy
#> cell_4  68.49701 13951.186
#> cell_5  73.80242 18085.385
#> cell_6 119.55364  3143.897
#> cell_7 105.25295  2191.132

#> 1  cell_4

#> 5  cell_8

    This function populates the nbr.expr, own.norm.scaled.expr and nbr.norm.scaled.expr slots with their corresponding matrices.

    We compute cluster information based on the gene-cell and neighbour feature-cell matrix.

    bank <- ClusterBanksy(bank)
#> 
#>  external python path provided and will be used
#> Iteration 1 out of 1
#> Consider to install these (optional) packages to run all possible Giotto commands:  RTriangle FactoMiner
#>  Giotto does not automatically install all these packages as they are not absolutely required and this reduces the number of dependencieshvg  was not found in the gene metadata information, all genes will be used
#> Finished clustering for Lambda=0.5, Resolution=1.2, K Neighbours=30
#> 35.23 sec elapsed

    Subsetting

    SubsetBanksy allows users to subset a BanksyObject by dimension, genes, cells, and metadata columns. The BanksyObject can be subset by dimensions with logical unquoted conditions. The variables here (e.g. sdimx) must correspond to the columns names of the cell.locs(bank).

    bankSubsetDim <- SubsetBanksy(bank,
                              dimx = sdimx > 1000 & sdimx < 4000,
                              dimy = sdimy > 2000 & sdimy < 3000)
#> Before filtering: 6725 cells and 140 genes.
#> After filtering: 117 cells and 140 genes.
#> Filtered 6608 cells and 0 genes.
head(bankSubsetDim)
#> own expression:
#>          cell_364 cell_367 cell_371 cell_384 cell_389
#> Slc1a2          6        5        0       33        6
#> Scn4b           0        1        0        0        0
#> Itpr1           4        5        0        2        1
#> Slc25a23        1        2        1        6        1
#> Slc1a3          0        6        2        5        3
#> 
#> neighbour expression:
#>               cell_364  cell_367  cell_371   cell_384   cell_389
#> Slc1a2.nbr   11.305456 14.966304 15.484280 12.9835741 11.3417701
#> Scn4b.nbr     2.733709  1.568674  0.309916  0.5667886  0.2673202
#> Itpr1.nbr     7.094486  7.205978  2.281497  3.6982651  1.9505708
#> Slc25a23.nbr  3.715010  3.360880  2.179115  2.7037227  3.1163111
#> Slc1a3.nbr    6.838900  2.413382  8.491142  7.9822000  7.7610144
#> 
#> own normalized scaled expression:
#>             cell_364   cell_367   cell_371   cell_384   cell_389
#> Slc1a2    1.16034574  0.2510181 -1.0862284  2.0340135 -0.1501558
#> Scn4b    -0.89551531 -0.4639751 -0.8955153 -0.8955153 -0.8955153
#> Itpr1     1.46819475  1.1868221 -1.1579503 -0.8263663 -0.8843935
#> Slc25a23  0.02391251  0.6036969  0.2815944  0.7208250 -0.7652384
#> Slc1a3   -0.67068773  2.4507634  1.0634518  0.2489317  0.2397355
#> 
#> neighbour normalized scaled expression:
#>                 cell_364    cell_367   cell_371   cell_384    cell_389
#> Slc1a2.nbr   -0.04780222  0.55959368  0.6455345  0.2306257 -0.04177705
#> Scn4b.nbr    -0.61062764 -0.83311725 -1.0735055 -1.0244499 -1.08164009
#> Itpr1.nbr     0.02134256  0.04567211 -1.0289318 -0.7197695 -1.10114554
#> Slc25a23.nbr -0.13363567 -0.40652191 -1.3171662 -0.9129140 -0.59498152
#> Slc1a3.nbr    0.99700794 -0.42468052  1.5277874  1.3642908  1.29323534
#> 
#> cell locations:
#>             sdimx    sdimy
#> cell_364 1019.050 2660.030
#> cell_367 1040.727 2585.758
#> cell_371 1023.696 2257.813
#> cell_384 1082.720 2383.199
#> cell_389 1084.240 2254.025
#> 
#> metadata:
#>      cell_ID res1.2_lam0.5_k30
#> 352 cell_364                 3
#> 355 cell_367                 2
#> 359 cell_371                 6
#> 372 cell_384                 6
#> 377 cell_389                 6

    The object can also be subset by cells with logical unquoted conditions:

    bankSubsetCells <- SubsetBanksy(bank,
                                cells = c(cell_364, cell_367, cell_384, cell_389))
#> Before filtering: 6725 cells and 140 genes.
#> After filtering: 4 cells and 140 genes.
#> Filtered 6721 cells and 0 genes.

    Similarly, the object can also be subset by any metadata column with logical unquoted conditions. Here, we select cells in clusters 4 to 6 based on the clustering with res=1.2, lam=0.5, k=30.

    bankSubsetMeta <- SubsetBanksy(bank,
                               metadata = res1.2_lam0.5_k30 %in% 4:6)
#> Before filtering: 6725 cells and 140 genes.
#> After filtering: 1894 cells and 140 genes.
#> Filtered 4831 cells and 0 genes.

    Subsetting by genes can be achieved by supplying a character vector of genes to the features argument.

    set.seed(42)
genes <- sample(rownames(own.expr(bank)), 10)
bankSubsetFeatures <- SubsetBanksy(bank,
                                   features = genes)
#> Before filtering: 6725 cells and 140 genes.
#> After filtering: 6725 cells and 10 genes.
#> Filtered 0 cells and 130 genes.

    If multiple subsetting features are supplied, the intersection of all conditions will be returned.
